descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An introduction to economics with an emphasis on macroeconomics (business cycles, inflation, unemployment, economic growth). The first three weeks cover aspects of general microeconomics that everyone should know, including how the market system works, how prices are determined, why shortages and surpluses occur, and basic industrial competition. Topics include: supply and demand, competition versus monopoly, comparative advantage in trade, taxation, and market failures. The last two-thirds of the class build on these tools to study the behavior of the economy as a whole, particularly in an international context. Topics include: inflation, unemployment, recessions, booms, fiscal and monetary policy, budget deficits, economic development of nations, international trade, and exchange rates.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: The class requires high school level algebra and the interpretation and use of graphs.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three 50 minute lectures and one fifty minute TA section per week.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two midterms (worth 15% and 30%), weekly quizzes (10%) and a final exam (45%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1. Macroeconomics (3rd or 4th edition) by Paul Krugman, Robin Wells; ISBN-10: 1464110379, ISBN-13: 978-1464110375, Paper Text, 595 pages. Books will be ordered for the campus bookstore but are probably cheaper online.
2. Sapling online homework system (Will contain an offer for an e-text for Krugman/Wells)
3. Economics: A Very Short Introduction by Partha Dasgupta; 1st edition; Oxford Press, ISBN-13: 978-0192853455.
4. New Ideas from Dead Economists by Buchholz; any edition (ISBN: 978-0452288447).
